details.title: System Maintenance Scheduling With Prognostics Information Using Genetic Algorithm
details.standardTitle: System Maintenance Scheduling With Prognostics Information Using Genetic Algorithm

p: Fatih Camci is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer Engineering at Fatih University, Istanbul, Turkey. He worked as senior project engineer at Impact Technologies in Rochester, NY for two years with experience in the development of diagnostic/prognostic strategies for naval ship systems, and military aircraft applications. Camci received his PhD in Industrial Engineering from Wayne State University. He received his B.S. degree in Computer Engineering from Istanbul University (Turkey), and M.S. degree in Computer Engineering from Fatih University (Turkey). He has been involved in the development of optimum maintenance scheduling tools, and diagnostics/prognostic methods for naval ship systems. His expertise includes computational intelligence methods such as neural networks, fuzzy logic, support vector machines; and optimization methods such as linear, quadratic optimization, and genetic algorithms.

authors.affiliation: Comput. Eng. Dept., Fatih Univ., Istanbul, Turkey
authors.name: Fatih Camci

details.abstract: Condition based maintenance (CBM) aims to balance two extreme sides (i.e., corrective maintenance (CM), and preventive maintenance (PM)) by observing and forecasting the real time health of machines. Recent developments in CBM revealed promising technologies for advanced fault detection, and forecasting. Traditional maintenance scheduling in CBM is based on the threshold setting on forecasted failure probability, or remaining useful life (RUL) for individual components. However, this approach may not give the best result for the system, because individual components are inter-related, and mutually dependent. It is not uncommon in systems that turning off a machine due to failure or maintenance causes other machinery or components to be turned off. Designing a comprehensive tool that optimizes availability & cost of the whole system incorporating prognostics information is crucial to fully benefit from CBM. The goal of this paper is to emphasize this need by demonstrating scenarios in CM, PM, and CBM; and to present a solution that optimizes system availability, and cost with system-maintenance constraints using genetic algorithms. The proposed tool acquires the forecasted failure probability of individual components from the prognostics module, and their reliability expectations after maintenance. The tradeoff between maintenance & failure is quantified in risk as the objective function to be minimized. The risk is minimized utilizing genetic algorithms for the whole system rather than individual components. The results of the proposed tool are compared with PM, CM, and CBM in which prognostics information of components are analyzed individually.

links.abstract: We examine how to reduce the adverse effects of machine down time by prioritizing production equipment for attention by a limited number of maintenance personnel. The maintenance scheduling policies use system information to determine which machines are the most critical at a given time. This information includes repair times, queue lengths, due dates, available capacity, and steady-state utilizations. The effects of different staffing levels are also considered. Many utilities are now firmly interconnected with neighbouring utilities and generating capacity planning is conducted on a fully or semi-integrated basis. This paper presents a method based on the Gram-Charlier expansion for evaluating maintenance schedules in two interconnected power utilities using a levelized reliability criterion. This paper also investigates the effect of changing one utility p...

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[29].
In [24], Maillart et. al. present an age-replacement policy that optimizes cost or availability for serial multi-machine systems.
Even if these methods [24]–[29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.

multi-machine systems with non-instantaneous repairs
references.text: L. M. Maillart, X. Fang, "Optimal maintenance policies for serial multi-machine systems with non-instantaneous repairs", Naval Research Logistics, vol. 53, no. 8, pp. 804-813, 2006.

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[25][29].
The paper [25] aims to optimize testing and maintenance intervals of safety related equipment based on unavailability & cost criteria.
Even if these methods [24]–[25][29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.

references.title:
Addressing imperfect maintenance
modelling uncertainty in unavailability and cost based optimization
references.text: A. Sanchez, S. Carlos, S. Martorell, J. F. Villanueva, "Addressing imperfect maintenance modelling uncertainty in unavailability and cost based optimization", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 94, no. 1, pp. 22-32, 2009.

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[26][29].
In [26], maintenance periods are taken as decision variables to the optimization model that represents a system with multiple interconnected, interdependent components.
Even if these methods [24]–[26][29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.

references.title:

uncertainty for RAMS <ref_formula><tex Notation="TeX">$+$</tex></ref_formula>C
optimization
references.text: S. Martorell, A. Sanchez, S. Carlo, "A tolerance interval based approach to address uncertainty for RAMS \$+\$C optimization", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 92, no. 4, pp. 408-422, 2007.

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[27][29].
In [27], optimization is performed by formalizing economic constraints in terms of an energy or cost function, and using the maintenance period as the control parameter.
Even if these methods [24]–[27][29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[28][29].
In [28], the authors search the number of preventive maintenance actions to be performed in the life cycle (or during the study period) of all system components.
Even if these methods [24]–[28][29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.

context.text: There exist reliability- and risk-based methods formulating the objective function for the optimality of the system rather than its components [24]–[29].
In [29], the optimization model of the preventive maintenance period of a nuclear power-plant is presented.
Even if these methods [24]–[29] focus on the system risk minimization, they identify the period of the preventive (periodic) maintenance.
